For key 7, floor(76/7)=10.
For key 8, floor(224/8)=28 exactly.
For key 9, floor(467/9)=51.
For key 11, floor(1155/11)=105.
For key 12, floor(2683/12)=223.

That seems more plausible: f(n) is the quotient when dividing k_n by n. And note that sometimes k_n/n is an integer (like for 8 and 11), and sometimes not (like for 7,9,12).

Thus final answer: 
f(7) = 10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105, and f(12)=223.

And the remainders are g(7)=6, g(8)=0, g(9)=8, g(11)=0, g(12)=7.
That is likely what they want.

I'll answer: 
The keys k_n satisfy k_n = n * f(n) + g(n). For key 7, 76 = 7*10+6 so f(7)=10; for key 8, 224=8*28+0 so f(8)=28; for key 9, 467=9*51+8 so f(9)=51; for key 11, 1155=11*105+0 so f(11)=105; and for key 12 (which also equals k_8×12 -5), we have 2683=12*223+7, so f(12)=223.

I'll now produce the final answer accordingly.</think>We are told that each “key” kₙ can be written in the form

  kₙ = n·f(n) + g(n).

In many cases (and in particular for some of the keys below) the division is exact so that f(n) is an integer; when it isn’t, one may think of f(n) as the “quotient” and g(n) as the remainder. In our example we have five keys:

  • Key 7: k₇ = 76  
  • Key 8: k₈ = 224  
  • Key 9: k₉ = 467  
  • Key 11: k₁₁ = 1155  
  • Key 12: k₁₂ is given by the relation k₁₂ = (k₈ × 12) – 5

Let’s find f(n) in each case.

–––––––––––
Step 1. Key 7

We have
  76 = 7·f(7) + g(7).

Divide 76 by 7:
  76 ÷ 7 = 10 remainder 6  (since 7×10 = 70 and 76 – 70 = 6).

Thus we can write
  76 = 7·10 + 6,
so that

  f(7) = 10 and g(7) = 6.
–––––––––––
Step 2. Key 8

We have
  224 = 8·f(8) + g(8).

Divide 224 by 8:
  224 ÷ 8 = 28 exactly (since 8×28 = 224 with no remainder).

Thus,
  f(8) = 28 and g(8) = 0.
–––––––––––
Step 3. Key 9

We have
  467 = 9·f(9) + g(9).

Divide 467 by 9:
  467 ÷ 9 = 51 remainder 8  (because 9×51 = 459 and 467 – 459 = 8).

Thus,
  f(9) = 51 and g(9) = 8.
–––––––––––
Step 4. Key 11

We have
  1155 = 11·f(11) + g(11).

Divide 1155 by 11:
  1155 ÷ 11 = 105 exactly (since 11×105 = 1155).

Thus,
  f(11) = 105 and g(11) = 0.
–––––––––––
Step 5. Key 12

We are told that
  k₁₂ = (k₈ × 12) – 5.

Since we already found k₈ = 224, compute:
  k₁₂ = (224×12) – 5 = 2688 – 5 = 2683.

Now write
  2683 = 12·f(12) + g(12).

Divide 2683 by 12:
  2683 ÷ 12 = 223 remainder 7  (because 12×223 = 2676 and 2683 – 2676 = 7).

Thus,
  f(12) = 223 and g(12) = 7.
–––––––––––

So, summarizing our answers:

  • For key 7: f(7) = 10  
  • For key 8: f(8) = 28  
  • For key 9: f(9) = 51  
  • For key 11: f(11) = 105  
  • For key 12: f(12) = 223

In many puzzles of this type the “nice” ones are those where kₙ divides evenly by n (so that g(n) = 0), as happens for keys 8 and 11. In our list, keys 7, 9, and 12 leave a nonzero remainder.

This is one acceptable answer.
